qas.question: What are the physics of quantum mechanics?

answers.text: mathematics of Hilbert spaces and linear operators acting on them
determination of the position of a particle prevents the determination of its momentum and vice versa

qas.question: The physics of quantum mechanics included special cases for what work?

answers.text: formulations of both Heisenberg and Schrödinger

context: The physics of quantum mechanics was thereby reduced to the <a0_0>mathematics of Hilbert spaces and linear operators acting on them<a0_0/>. For example, the uncertainty principle, according to which the <a1_0>determination of the position of a particle prevents the determination of its momentum and vice versa<a1_0/>, is translated into the non-commutativity of the two corresponding operators. This new mathematical formulation included as special cases the <a2_0>formulations of both Heisenberg and Schrödinger<a2_0/>. When Heisenberg was informed von Neumann had clarified the difference between an unbounded operator that was a Self-adjoint operator and one that was merely symmetric, Heisenberg replied "Eh? What is the difference?"
